metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Object Accessors
JavaScript Accessors (Getters and Setters)
ECMAScript 5 (ES5 2009) introduced Getter and Setters.
Getters and setters allow you to define Object Accessors (Computed Properties).
content.html: Getters and setters allow you to define Object Accessors (Computed Properties).

content.text: JavaScript Getter (The get Keyword)
This example uses a lang property to get the value of the language property.
content.html: This example uses a lang property to get the value of the language property.

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

syntax_highlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

content.code_html:
// Create an object:
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  language: "en",
  get lang() {
    return this.language;
  }
};

// Display data from the object using a getter:
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.lang;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

content.text: JavaScript Setter (The set Keyword)
This example uses a lang property to set the value of the language property.
content.html: This example uses a lang property to set the value of the language property.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Set an object 
property using a setter:

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Set an object 
property using a setter:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  language: "",
  set lang(lang) {
    this.language = lang;
  }
};

// Set an object property using a setter:
 person.lang = "en";

// Display data from the object:
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.language;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Set an object 
property using a setter:

content.text: JavaScript Function or Getter?
What is the differences between these two examples?
content.html: What is the differences between these two examples?

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a method:

syntax_highlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a method:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  fullName: function() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
};

// Display data from the object using a method:
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.fullName();

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Display data from the object using a method:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

syntax_highlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  get fullName() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
};

// Display data from the object using a getter:
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.fullName;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

content.text: Example 1 access fullName as a function: person.fullName().
content.html: Example 1 access fullName as a function: person.fullName().

content.text: Example 2 access fullName as a property: person.fullName.
content.html: Example 2 access fullName as a property: person.fullName.

content.text: The second example provides a simpler syntax.
content.html: The second example provides a simpler syntax.

content.text: Data Quality
JavaScript can secure better data quality when using getters and setters.
content.html: JavaScript can secure better data quality when using getters and setters.

content.text: Using the lang property, in this example, returns the value of the language property in upper case:
content.html: Using the lang property, in this example, returns the value of the language property in upper case:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

syntax_highlighting.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

content.code_html:
// Create an object:
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  language: "en",
  get lang() {
    return this.language.toUpperCase();
  }
};

// Display data from the object using a getter:
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.lang;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Display data from the object using a getter:

content.text: Using the lang property, in this example, stores an upper case value in the language property:
content.html: Using the lang property, in this example, stores an upper case value in the language property:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Set an object 
property using a setter:

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Set an object 
property using a setter:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  language: "",
  set lang(lang) {
    this.language = lang.toUpperCase();
  }
};

// Set an object property using a setter:
 person.lang = "en";

// Display data from the object:
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.language;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Set an object 
property using a setter:

content.text: Why Using Getters and Setters?
Object.defineProperty()
The Object.defineProperty() method can also be used to add Getters and Setters:
content.html: The Object.defineProperty() method can also be used to add Getters and Setters:

content.code_html:
// Define object
 const obj = {counter : 0};

// Define setters and getters
 Object.defineProperty(obj, "reset", {
  get : function () {this.counter = 0;}
});
Object.defineProperty(obj, "increment", {
  get : function () {this.counter++;}
});
Object.defineProperty(obj, "decrement", {
  get : function () {this.counter--;}
});
Object.defineProperty(obj, "add", {
  set : function (value) {this.counter += value;}
});
Object.defineProperty(obj, "subtract", {
  set : function (value) {this.counter -= value;}
});

// Play with the counter:
 obj.reset;
obj.add = 5;
obj.subtract = 1;
obj.increment;
obj.decrement;
